data.name: Collecting Hailstones
data.description:
One day I was doodling when I looked up at the sky. I wondered why oh why are there heavy hailstones in the sky.

This got me thinking about algorithms.

The hailstone algorithm is defined by the function h(n) where n can be any positive integer

h(n) = n/2 if n is even or 3n + 1 if n is odd

A sequence is created by taking the last h(n) and re-inserting into the formula. So n' = h(n) which leads to the next h(n') etc.

A hailstone sequence repeats once h(n) reduces to 1 (actually the sequence recurrs from there becoming 1, 4, 2, 1...)

But we'll finish the sequence once we find the first 1. We then count the terms that it took to find 1. 

So for example H(6) = 6, 3, 10, 5, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1
The code that would generate H(6) has 9 terms

My interest was finding hailstones with a large number of terms by iterating through all known integers.

Let's find some!
